_header: Most worthy prince of whom the noble fame
Subjects: Holy Church; political poems; advice, to princes
_description: A Defence of Holy Church, by Lydgate — twenty-one stanzas rhyme royal

BLHar1245.First Lines: MOst worthi prince of whome the noble fameIn vertue floureth and in hih policy prudence…
BLHar1245.Last Lines: …In Babilon with a soden fallWhan þat the honde wrote vpon the wall
BLHar1245.Note: In line 2, “policy” first written and then crossed through before “prudence”; “finis pri[ci]pii”" in lower margin in code, f. 183rb.

BLSl1212.First Lines:
Most worthy prynce off whome þe noble fameIn vertu flouryth
                    & in hygh prudence…
BLSl1212.Last Lines:
…The schippe gan rest out off all dawyngeMaugre þe rokys
                    off vengeaunce mercyles
BLSl1212.Note:
Stanzas 1-8; ends incomplete, seven stanzas rhyme royal plus two lines
                    of eighth stanza; in top margin of fol. 3, drawing of bull’s head with
                    scroll, ‘Laste ne[…]’; bottom margin f. 3v,
                    ‘ȝoures allone with outyn otheris parte’ and ‘Mon
                        euere ma dite qui serra Ieoyous’.
BLSl1212.Editions:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             John Lydgate: Poems.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1966: 30.
